data.text: Contents
Missing and absconding patient policy general principles .......................................... 11
Introduction

The Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to fulfilling its duty of care for the safety of its patients. The Trust recognises that people admitted to the Trust are assumed to be voluntary and have a legal right to leave the hospital of their own free will unless they are detained under the Mental Health Act 1983 and 2007; the Mental Capacity Act's Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards 2009or are a prisoner in custody receiving treatment at the Trust. Whilst many patients are able to leave the ward area / department without harm occurring, some patients may be at risk, either from others, to themselves, or to others.
This policy advises staff of action to be taken and by whom in the event of an adult or child being identified as missing.

This policy has been written to ensure effective interagency procedures exist in the event of a patient being identified as missing and has been revised following lessons learned from previous instances of missing patients.
Consideration should be given to the patient's status with regard to mental health act and the Mental Capacity Act concerning their ability to make an informed decision about leaving the ward area.
The Trust needs to be vigilant in the care of all its patients particularly those who are vulnerable to going missing. This includes those that are:
a) self-harming / suicidal risk
b) a young person under the age of 18 and unable to protect themselves
c) confused / disoriented / suffering from delirium
d) suffering from the symptoms of Dementia
e) depressed or other symptoms of mental illness
f) dependant on alcohol or illicit substances
g) known to have a history of previous incidents of absconding
h) known to have a cognitive impairment

All occurrences of a patient going missing or not returning from authorised leave at an agreed time must be reported in line with the Trust's Policy for Incident reporting in addition to the requirements of this policy.

Measures implemented to prevent a patient going missing or not returning from authorised leave at an agreed time must be reported on the Trust Incident reporting system in addition to the requirements of this policy.

All staff have a responsibility for ensuring that procedures are in place to avoid a patient going missing from a clinical area, these include closing the ward doors and ensuring that the patient is wearing Trust identification bracelets.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Establish a policy to proportionally and appropriately manage the risk of a patient going missing from an inpatient or outpatient episode.
Identify actions to minimise the risk of patient going missing
Identify the process to be followed if a patient is suspected or confirmed as missing
Identify the process of reporting the risk factors associated with a missing patient

To comply with the principles and requirements of the Mental Health Act 1983 and 2007, the Human Rights Act 1998, the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (including the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards 2009) and the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984
This policy applies to all Trust inpatient, outpatient and Emergency Department settings.
Definitions

table_items.text: A missing patient is defined as any inpatient, outpatient or emergency department patient who is noted to be absent from the ward / area / department, without prior arrangement / notification or is overdue returning to the ward from authorised leave. This can be an adult, child or infant (but excludes babies missing from maternity services)

Is where a patient who is liable to be detained under the Mental Health Act 1983, is detained under MCA DOLS, is subject to a Public Health Order, is in custody of the Police or Prison Service leaves the treatment area without permission from a clinical staff member, or where a patient fails to return to the inpatient unit at the completion of an approved period of leave

The College of Policing (CoP) Authorised Professional practice (APP) places all missing persons within a Continuum of Risk ranging from ‘no apparent risk (absent)' through to High Risk cases that require immediate, intensive action
The person / Nurse in charge of the area/ ward/department at the time of the incident

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Trust Health and Safety Management Group: - The Trust Health and Safety Management Group will ensure that reports received from the site Health and safety Forums, the SMD or the LSMS are reviewed and acted upon including passing information and guidance to the Trust SMD and the Trust LSMS.

Site Health and Safety Forums: - The Trust's site Health and Safety Forums will ensure that reports received from the SMD, or LSMS or site staff are reviewed and acted upon including passing information and guidance to the Trust Health and Safety Management Group, the SMD and the LSMS as appropriate.
Chief Executive
Has overall responsibility for the safe and legal implementation of this policy.
The Chief Estates and Facilities Officer

Is responsible for the role of the Security Management Director (SMD) and is responsible for overseeing and providing strategic management and support for all security management work within the organisation
Facilities Managers
Are responsible for disseminating the policy to Estate / Security Managers / Supervisor
Care Group Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Deputy Director of Operations (DDO)

The DDO's are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Deputy and Associate Directors of Nursing (DDoN / ADoN)

The DDoNS and ADoN's are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Security Staff on shift are responsible for:
Once they are notified of a missing patient, assisting in the co-ordinated search of the site as directed by the Matron or Nurse in charge of the ward.
The search should include all hospital grounds as well as CCTV review.

If not found on the Internal Site Search the search will be expanded by the Co- ordinator and Security search organiser to the outside of the building; unless presenting CCTV data has already shown the individual exiting the building (
in which case the Security search organiser will have already escalated the search criteria).
The external site search will include grounds/wooded areas and buildings within hospital perimeter, car parks.
Notifying the Nurse in charge of the ward of the outcome of any search.

Subject to patient Risk level and judgements made in real time (Dynamic risk assessment) the security officer on shift can leave site and/or assist Police where reasonably requested to do so by Emergency Services in a wider search for the patient.

Decisions taken are subject to a balance of risk and consideration should be given towards – The duty of care owed to the missing patient against the risk of not having a security officer on site whilst the wider search is conducted.

Circumstances may arise whereby the security officer on shift is attending another call (e.g. a violent patient) and may be unable to assist in the search. In this instance, the Nurse in charge of the ward should seek advice from the Matron (or Clinical Site Coordinator if out of hours) as to what other resources may be reasonably sourced (porters/ support staff from another ward) to assist in the search.
Matrons will be responsible for supporting the nurse in charge with regards to coordinating the search for the missing patient. This includes:
Assisting in the search of the premises and grounds of the hospital
Allocation of staff from other areas to assist in the search
Sharing information and updates that may be received from third parties with the nurse in charge responsible for the search.
Provide assurances and support decisions regarding contacting the Police (where the criteria for a Police Welfare Check has been met).

The level of Matron support will vary depending on what time of day that the incident occurs, i.e. in hours or out of hours and the determined level of risk and patient vulnerability as relayed to them by the ward nurse in charge.
Clinical Site Co-ordinator is responsible for supporting the Nurse in Charge regarding the coordination of the search for the missing patient out of hours. This includes:
Assisting in the search of the premises and grounds
Sharing information and updates that may be received from third parties with the nurse in charge responsible for the search.
Provide assurances and support decisions as to contacting the Police (where criteria has been met for welfare checks)
Escalating to the Senior Manager On Call (SMOC) if the patient goes missing out of hours
Nurse in Charge of the ward is responsible for the following actions upon notification that a patient is missing from the ward, service or department under their control:
Co-ordination of an initial search of the ward / area that the patient is reported missing from with methodical checks of all patient rooms, bathrooms, toilets, staff only areas, store cupboards etc.
Co-ordination of a wider search (if patient not found during the initial search) including corridors, communal areas, grounds and gardens.

Report the missing patient to the Matron (and the Clinical site co-ordinator if out of hours) for support and advice as to what resources are available to assist in the wider search, relaying information concerning the level of risk and vulnerability of the patient.
Subject to risk levels and patient vulnerability, decide if:
Informing the next of kin. Establishing if they might know where the missing patient might go (e.g. will they attempt to go home, visit a friend, head to a location that is well known to them)
Discuss with staff to check if the patient has been expressing an intention to leave and establish if a location has been mentioned.
Ensure that the Matron/ Clinical site co-ordinator, next of kin and any other person involved with the search are kept updated and informed of actions taken, progress and outcomes.
Ensuring that an incident report (DATIX) is completed in accordance with the Trust Procedure for the reporting and management of Incidents and serious incidents MSEPO 19015.
Ward Staff
Are responsible for:
Reporting to the Nurse in Charge where they suspect a patient to be absent or missing
Assisting in the search for the missing patient as directed by the Nurse in charge
Attending and escorting any ‘found' patient back to the ward when it is safe to do so.
All Trust Staff
Are responsible for complying with this policy and actions therein.
All incidents where patients have absconded or are missing must be reported in accordance with the Trust Procedure for the reporting and management of Incidents and serious incidents MSEPO 19015.

4.14.1 The person completing the incident report (DATIX) may vary, but typically will be a member of staff as instructed by the nurse in charge of the shift. Consider completing a safeguarding referral if the patient is considered an adult at risk and if there is evidence to suggest that neglect or omission contributed to the patient going missing. Staff should always seek guidance from the MSE Safeguarding Team if in doubt.
Categorisation of risk levels

These are to be used when assessing the level of risk for missing patients to ensure a consistent approach and response. This is not an exhaustive list and taking the following details into consideration, cases may vary, based on the person specific risk assessment that has been undertaken. These Risk categories have been agreed with Essex Police.
High risk
5.2.1 Those patients who are an immediate risk and have a significant likelihood to suffer harm to them as an individual or as a threat to others.
5.2.2 An old person who is dependent upon the assistance of another responsible person (e.g. relative or carer) and is likely to face immediate and significant harm in the absence of that person.

5.2.3 An infant or child who is dependent upon the assistance of another responsible person (e.g. relative or carer) and is likely to face immediate and significant harm in the absence of that person.
5.2.4 A child that is on the Child Protection Register, with aggravating indicators such as abuse at any level which escalates their risk category.

5.2.5 A patient who is assessed as likely to attempt significant self-harm or suicide. This assessment will be based on all relevant information indicating the individual's state of mind e.g., medical history, current mental health management plan, reason for admission into hospital, mental health risk assessment on admission.

5.2.6 A patient who does not have the mental capacity to make a decision regarding discharge arrangements and who could be classified as a vulnerable adult e.g. a patient who is confused, has dementia, amnesia or with a significant learning disability.

5.2.7 A patient that is assessed as likely to come to harm without medical assistance. This category includes patients who go missing without their medication and who are then in immediate risk to themselves or are a risk to others.
5.2.8 A minor who may be at risk of abduction.
Medium risk
5.3.1 These are patients who may normally be responsible and able, who through injury or impairment of their reasoning may abscond from the departments.
5.3.2 A child that is on the Child Protection Register, who may normally be responsible and able otherwise.

5.3.3 A patient that is assessed as likely to come to harm without medical assistance. This category includes patients who go missing without their medication and who are then potentially at risk themselves or are a risk to others. Please note that the risk may escalate over time.

5.3.4 A patient who is known to be personally vulnerable due to previous associations with individuals who potentially may cause the patient harm, e.g. domestic violence victims, physical assault victims.
Please note that this may escalate dependent on individual circumstances.
Low risk

These are patients who are willingly absent, but are able to function adequately without assistance and are unlikely to come to harm under normal circumstances. It would also cover cases where despite consideration of known risk factors, there are still no grounds for believing the missing person is likely to come to harm.
Patients detained under the Mental Health Act (1983)
If a patient is detained under the Mental Health Act, he/she are not allowed to leave the hospital. If the patient absconds, then the Police have a duty to return that person to hospital.
Patients detained under Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DOLS) (2009)

If a patient is detained under DOLS he/she should not be allowed to leave hospital. If they are thought to have left the premises, the Police must be notified and asked to search for the patient and return them to the hospital. Next of kin/Parent/Carer and the Best Interest Assessor must be notified at the earliest opportunity. The line manager should be notified immediately and the on call manager when out of hours. Datix must be completed (refer to DOLS policy for further details).
Missing and absconding patient policy general principles

All staff should fully understand their powers and responsibilities regarding those patients who are being detained under the Mental Health Act (1983) and those patients for whom a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard has been instated

All patients must have two identification bands on their person which clearly state their Name (surname and first name) Date of birth, NHS Number and Hospital Number. (in accordance with the Patient identification Policy MSEPO – 21002)
Nursing staff in wards and departments must strive at all times to ensure that a patients' whereabouts is known.
Staff must make patients aware of the importance of telling them when they leave the ward or department area and when they return.
When a patient is transferred from one area to another, staff must ensure that they communicate this transfer to all relevant staff
Relatives and/or carers must be made aware of their responsibility to inform staff when taking a patient from the ward and return the patient when they are requested to do so by ward staff.

Staff responsible for clerking/booking in patients to departments must ensure that Next of Kin(NOK) information is obtained where possible and that patients' records are updated with NOK emergency contact details at the time of admission. Where a patient is unconscious or lacks capacity (e.g. on admission to the Emergency Department/ SDEC) all efforts must be undertaken to establish NOK information.

Thorough and accurate documentation is an essential part of the Missing and Absconding Patients Policy. All stages/ assessments/forms must be fully completed, documented and filed in the patients' records in accordance with the Trust Clinical Record Keeping Standards Policy.
If a patient wishes to take self-discharge, staff should make an effort to persuade the patient that it is in their best interest to remain in hospital to receive medical treatment.

If the patient still wishes to take their own discharge, and they have been assessed as having capacity to make that decision, then they must be asked to sign a self- discharge form. If the patient refuses to sign the form, the nurse must fully document the conversation they have had with the patient in the patient health record and attach the self-discharge form to the notes. MSEPO-21178 Joint discharge policy
If there are any doubts about the patient's mental capacity or wellbeing then an assessment should be made in accordance with the Trusts Mental Capacity Act Policy MSEPO-21103
Assessment on admission

Where there is knowledge of, or concern that, a patient has the potential to abscond due to confusion, mental illness with a history of self-harm or harm to others, the Missing Persons Risk Assessment MP1 should be completed (refer to appendix 1).

If the patient is thought to lack capacity and has an underlying mental health illness that is putting the patient or others at risk, the patient may be required to be detained under the Mental Health Act.
The consultant / duty clinician should liaise with the on-call psychiatric team (Crisis team) to request a psychiatric assessment.
Prior to the arrival of the psychiatric assessment team, the Police should be called and asked to attend the department to prevent the patient absconding if:
The patient is initially assessed by Trust medical staff and deemed to lack capacity for mental health reasons, and
Is believed to be imminently at risk of harm to themselves or others, and
Is actively trying to, or it is believed they will abscond.
The Trust security staff must also be called to assist with any immediate issues or if necessary safely restrain the patient before the police attend.

For all persons rated as Medium and High risk, the Missing Persons Description Form MP2 should be completed (refer to appendix 2). A photograph of the patient should be obtained as soon as possible to assist staff and Police with identifying the patient should they abscond or go missing.

Before any photographs are taken, patients should be asked to give informed consent. The patient must be asked to sign the photograph consent form, after an explanation has been given on how their images will be managed and used. The consent form (see Appendix 7) must be completed and placed in the patient's notes.

In hours, a digital photograph of the patient will be taken by the medical photography department by contacting the department between the hours of 0900-1700 (Monday to Friday) and a request should be made for them to come to the area where the patient is being cared for.
A master copy of the patient's digital clinical photograph will be stored on the Medical Photography database.
Medical Photography will notify the ward when the photographs are ready for collection by the ward.

Three working copies will be produced for the patient's medical records whilst they are an in-patient under the care of MSE Trust. These are to be kept with the MP2 pro forma and placed in the patient's notes in the inpatient episode section, along with a formal care plan set in place to manage the risk.
The completed form and care plan must be accessible to staff at all times.
The images stored on the medical photography system will remain MSE Property and can be regenerated by Medical Photography Staff only in the event of a readmission or recurrence.
Missing patient
The member of staff who identifies that a patient is missing must immediately inform the nurse in charge of the ward or department.
The bed area / immediate area must be searched to establish whether the patient has taken his or her belongings with them and to determine what they are likely to be wearing.
The nurse in charge will commence the ‘Missing Patient procedure' in accordance with the flow chart and agreed timelines as specified in Appendix 3 and
Time span – within 15 minutes
8.4.1 The nurse in charge will implement a thorough search of the ward or department including toilets, bathrooms, day rooms and cupboards

8.4.2 The nurse in charge should notify security that there is a patient missing from the ward area. Security operatives should be requested to attend the ward, to receive a briefing, as there may be a need to conduct a search

8.4.3 The nurse in charge will allocate members of staff who can recognise the patient to undertake an initial check of the public areas - the hospital entrance, restaurant, public toilets and shops - and will alert immediate the neighbouring wards or departments. The member of staff must be escorted by a member of the security team at all times during extended searches as they will be able to radio for assistance if required.

8.4.4 The nurse in charge will inform the Matron(in hours)/Clinical site coordinator (out of hours) that a patient is missing and communicate their name and a brief description and any other identifiable information e.g. known to be wearing night wear, no foot wear, confused, non-English speaking.
8.4.5 The nurse in charge will commence the Timeline Report – Appendix

8.4.6 The nurse in charge will inform the next of kin/parents/carers that the patient is missing only after this initial search has been conducted, to prevent undue worry to elderly or frail relatives. The nurse in charge will arrange to telephone relatives again within 45 minutes.

8.4.7 Where patients have been assessed as high/medium risk, the police should be notified. The police will require the following information of the patients description and will require staff to complete an Essex Police Checklist form (refer to appendix

5). This documents the patient description details for the police in their preferred format. This should be completed prior to contacting the police: additional information for some patients may be required such as the patients risk to themselves or others.
Time span - within 30 minutes
8.5.1 The nurse in charge will call and update the Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) and inform them of the level of risk.

8.5.2 The nurse in charge will inform the patient's consultant team or, out of hours, the on-call junior clinician responsible for the patient's care. The medical team will advise if there are particular concerns or any additional risks that must be taken into consideration.

8.5.3 If the patient is considered a high/medium risk patient, the Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will arrange for Medical Photography to produce additional copies of the patient's photographs. The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will then arrange for the MP1 form to be photocopied and will initiate a SECONDARY search of the hospital site in an agreed format. Copies of the MP1 form will be made available to staff involved in the search. The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will alert the main reception staff, Trust LSMS (if in hours), ED Department and Switchboard.
8.5.4 For those patients rated low risk, the nurse in charge will complete the MP1 form (appendix 1) prior to contacting the Police to advise them that a patient is missing and the category of risk.

8.5.5 If the patient is considered a low risk patient, the Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) with the nurse in charge will decide whether further action is required in the particular circumstances of the patient absconding. If no further search is warranted, the nurse in charge of the ward will inform the patient's GP, community or social care providers, community midwife (if applicable) and the next of kin/parent/carer.
No result from initial / and secondary searches – time span within  minutes

8.6.1 The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will inform the Deputy Chief Nurse and the Senior Manager on-call or, if out of hours, the Site Coordinator will update the Senior Manager on-call only.

8.6.2 Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) or nurse in charge for the area will update the next of kin/parents/carers of the situation and inform them that the police are now responsible for any further search.
8.6.3 The Deputy Chief Nurse or Senior Manager on call will inform the Executive Director on call.
8.6.4 The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will continue the timeline report.
No result from police search

8.7.1 The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) or lead nurse for the area will reassess every hour with the Senior Manager and / or Deputy Chief Nurse until the situation is resolved.

8.7.2 If the situation is not resolved within 4 hours, the Deputy Chief Nurse and / or the Senior Manager on call will ensure that the Chief Executive or the Executive Director on-call is made aware of the situation. The Chief Executive and Executive Director on call will decide together with the police whether further communication is required via the press, local TV and radio. If required, the Executive Director on call will inform the Trust Communications Manager.

8.7.3 The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will continue to contact the next of kin at least every 2 hours, except at night when contact will be by mutual agreement. If the patient remains missing for longer than 24 hours, contact will continue but at times agreed with the next of kin.
Location of patient

8.8.1 If the patient is located at any stage in the above process, the Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) must establish in accordance with the Patient Found flow chart (Appendix 6) the following:
The safety and medical condition of the patient.
Whether any treatment is necessary as part of this episode.
Whether the patient is to return voluntarily to complete their treatment or is to be formally discharged.
Whether the patient is at risk of going missing again.
8.8.2 Patients have the right to leave the hospital and should only be verbally persuaded t to remain unless they are an obvious risk to themselves or others.
In this situation as a last resort for adult patients only, minimum restraint may be used by trained security staff. But only if it is assessed as safe.
Immediate assistance must be sought from the Police if the patient has assaulted staff or others, or has managed to escape restraint and abscond again.
8.8.3 The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) must ensure that the next of kin/parents/carers are contacted at the earliest opportunity.

8.8.4 If the patient refuses to return to hospital, the patient's consultant or, the on-call consultant (out of hours) where possible should determine whether the patient has capacity to refuse treatment. If the patient has capacity, the medical team should refer the patient to the GP for ongoing care, initially via telephone and then in writing. Alternatively, referral to the on call social worker should be made.

8.8.5 If the patient is thought to lack capacity and has an underlying mental health illness that is putting the patient or others at risk, the patient may be required to be detained under the Mental Health Act. The consultant / duty clinician should liaise with the on-call psychiatric team.

8.8.6 Prior to psychiatric assessment team arrival: If the patient is initially assessed by Trust medical staff and deemed to lack capacity for mental health reasons, and is believed to be imminently at risk of harm to themselves or others, and is actively trying to or believed will abscond again, the Police should be called.
8.8.7 If the patient is at risk of absconding again the nurse in charge must update the risk assessment and reviewed the care plan to ensure future patient safety.
8.8.8 A copy of the timeline, a completed search plan and a completed incident form should be sent to the Governance Department.
8.8.9 Risk Assessment Form (MP1), and Timeline (MP4) should be filed in the patient's medical record.

8.8.10 The Matron (in hours) or Clinical Site Coordinator (out of hours) will ensure that the Deputy Chief Nurse, the Senior Manager, the Executive Director on call, the Security Team Leader and the Police (when involved) are informed of the patient being found.
8.8.11 Essex Police will retain the patient's image on the National Missing Persons Database, as there is a residual risk that the patient may repeat the attempt to abscond.

8.8.12 They must obtain the appropriate consent from either the patient or patients' legal representative in accordance with police procedures. It is considered that this is proportionate and necessary to protect the public interest and protect the vulnerable individual who is at risk.
8.8.13 Essex Police are charged with the same conditions in relation to confidentiality and disclosure in this respect and are bound by their own guidelines.
The Trust cannot be held responsible for decisions that Essex Police make in relation of the retention of images.
Unsuccessful location of patient or patient harmed or found deceased
8.9.1 In the event of the patient being harmed or not located after an agreed time span, a formal investigation will be initiated by the Chief Nurse and the Serious Incident Management Group.
8.9.2 Reports will be required from all staff within the Trust who were involved in the incident and from other services outside the Trust who supported the process.
“Left before treatment” patients (ED, plastics/burns, assessment areas)
8.10.1 This situation applies to the Emergency patients predominantly seen via Emergency Department, Burns and Plastics unit and Assessment areas.
The procedure is described in the ‘Left before Treatment flow chart' in Appendix  In addition, staff should ensure that they consider the Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards.
8.10.2 The member of staff suspecting that a patient may have left before treatment should first determine whether this is so by:
Calling them 3 times at intervals
Checking all relevant areas of the Department – waiting room, cubicles, corridor, interview room and toilets.
Considering whether the patient is deaf or may not be unable to understand English.
8.10.3 If the patient has actually left before treatment, the nurse in charge of the department must decide whether further action is required. This may include:
Contacting the patient at home by telephone
Speaking to the psychiatric team to advise them of any concerns- particularly in case of self-harm or possible psychiatric problems

Contacting the Police to retrieve the patient if he/she lacks capacity or has a significant mental disorder (seek advice from psychiatric team where appropriate) Complete an MP2 form to aid the police in identifying the patient
Contacting the Police to ask if they would do a ‘welfare check' at the patient's
home address
8.10.4 If a patient is threatening to leave before treatment, the nurse in charge of that area should:
Speak to the patient, or arrange for someone more senior to speak to the patient, about their concerns
Discuss with the patient the risks of leaving before treatment
Decide whether the patient has capacity to determine the risks and benefits of leaving before treatment

8.10.5 If a patient is threatening to leave before treatment following an episode of self- harm or if the patient has presented with possible psychiatric problems, the nurse in charge of the area should:
Undertake a missing persons risk assessment to assess level of risk to the patient and others – Appendix 1
Refer to the nurse in charge of the department and the Consultant for advice
Refer to the Crisis team for an urgent assessment and advice
Ensure that a quiet area is made available in which to speak to the patient
Determine whether the patient is known to the Mental Health services and where possible obtain information of any current management plan.
Obtain risk and background information from escorting ambulance staff, family
and friends and police.

8.10.6 If the patient is thought to lack capacity and has an underlying mental health illness that is putting the patient or others at risk, the patient may be required to be detained under the Mental Health Act. The consultant / duty clinician should liaise with the on-call psychiatric team.

8.10.7 Prior to psychiatric assessment team arrival, if the patient is deemed to lack capacity for mental health reasons and is believed will abscond or actively trying to, then the police should be called.

8.10.8 The Trust security staff must also be called to assist with any immediate issues e.g. follow the patient should they attempt to abscond, or if necessary and safe to do so at clinical request, restrain the patient before the police attend. Restraining the patient must be the last resort and should never put any staff at risk of harm.
8.10.9 All relevant details should be recorded on the patient's AandE card before filing.
Training requirements
Outline training requirements or if not appropriate state: No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Outcome of security involvement in missing patient searches
Health and Safety Management Group / LSMS
Outcomes of untoward incidents of Patients missing or absconded

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Safeguarding Committee and the DoNS/ DDoNs Group and the Health and safety committee, which are the specialist groups with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the Safeguarding Committee and the DoNS/ DDoNs Group and the Health and safety committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 8)

Missing and absconding patients policy/MSEPO-21205 /1.0
Page  of
Attach  Medway  Pas Appendix 1: MSE NHS Hospitals Missing and Absconding Patient Risk Assessment MP1  Sticker here
RISK TITLE Generic – missing persons – MP1 form
ASSESSMENT: DATE:
Assessor/s
INTRODUCTION:

This assessment is generic. It is designed so that the information requirements and guidance to consider and assess the individual patients' risks can be identified and an action plan organised to effectively manage the patients' security whilst under the care of MSE NHS TRUST. Throughout this assessment  staff  must  operate  within  the  legislation  related  to  mental  capacity  and  deprivation  of  liberty.
Guidance notes in blue

table_items.text: PROPOSED / SUGGESTED CONTROLS add in further suggestions as required
Patient has been diagnosed with cognitive impairment (dementia, septic confusion, hypoxic et.c)
Patient may come to significant harm if absconding from the ward

Completion of patient profile and description. Kept in notes Guidance : Consider here how much assistance does the patient need, are they able to take care of some functions, are they lucid to some extent that they can be “told” and will do as told.

If patient is considered medium/high an MP1 form should be completed digital photo should be taken and kept with the patient profile. Permission for the photo must be obtained by either the patient or their representative. Full explanation of the reasons to be afforded to the representative. Notify all staff on the ward that the patient is H/M/L rated for risk of absconding. Consider 1:1 nursing within the care plan Discuss with the patient/representative the best options for care

data.text: Missing and absconding patients policy / MSEPO-21205 / 1.0
Page  of

table_items.text: Patient has been identified as self harming prior to admission
Patient could abscond from the ward and further harm themselves

Guidance: Consider the level of wounding and further risk of wounding that has/may occur. Do you consider that the patient needs to be supervised more closely, is liable to flee, or is a threat to themselves or others,
Patient may abscond to the pub, or obtain drugs for their habit
Guidance: Consider the nature of the addiction and the level of the addiction, and the appropriate treatments that can be applied to prevent this.
Care plan to reflect the level of addiction and the interventions that have been recommended (e.g. patches for smokers).
Patients who are considered to be Vulnerable

Guidance: whichever area of vulnerability the patient falls into, (eg paediatrics, elderly). Staff should ensure that they are clear of the nature of the vulnerability, for example domestic abuse – 3rd party abuser)

The patient is consulted where possible, to ensure that all avenues of vulnerability/abuse are explored. Where relevant this will direct the care plan for adequate management and security provision for the patient.
Where there is a considered threat for abduction to take place which will put patient and staff at risk
Guidance: speak with patient and/or representative as to any concerns of abduction. Ascertain the family background and any extenuating circumstances.

If patient is considered medium/high an MP1 form should be completed Digital photo should be taken and kept with the patient profile. Permission for the photo must be obtained by either the patient or their representative. Full explanation of the reasons to be afforded to the representative. Notify all staff on the ward that the patient is H/M/L rated for risk of absconding. Consider 1:1 nursing within the care plan Discuss with the patient/representative the best options for care
Patient is a carer for dependent / vulnerable other(s)
Harm may come to both the patient and or the dependent other

Guidance: where the present patient is also a carer or provides support to any other person who is dependent on them – e.g. presenting patient is carer for 30 yr. old disabled son… This will increase the risk not only for the presenting patient but in the care of the disabled/dependant other.
Ensure that full disclosure of any dependents is obtained on “basic history taking” documentation. Treat as high risk

data.text: SUMMARY and RECOMMENDATIONS:

After completing this risk assessment you should now have a good idea of the risk rating for the individual patient. In the action plan below state what needs to be done to ensure that this patient is kept safe. Remember that if there is a task, you must also allocate a person for that task and just as importantly tell them about the task
In all instances where the patient is considered “vulnerable” contact with the appropriate CNS should automatically be made.
In addition in all instances where there is inference that there may be physical or verbal abuse or a high risk of anti-social behaviour, Security should be alerted.
Action Plan – for monitoring by Risk Management / Health and Safety group

table_items.text: Patient likely to abscond from the ward
Complete patient information and description form
Arrange for digital photo to be taken
Arrange for appropriate consent to be given by either the patient or their representative
Place your additional requirements for action in here

data.text: DISTRIBUTION:

table_items.text: area lead / head or service – Acceptance of assessment, as indicated signed

The above assessment has been acknowledged and current controls; 13.1.1.1 Please delete below statements that are NOT APPLICABLE Provide adequate management of the risks at the present time Require additional resource and/or systems in place – as outlined in action plan Requires support of other directorates and monitoring through Health and Safety group- as outlined in the action plan Maintain the interim risks, prior to approval for management or system change– as outlined in above action plan Maintain interim risks, subject to health and safety group awareness of the affects to the strategic actions of the Trust – as outlined above
Remember anyone who has been given a task to do must be given a copy of this risk assessment

Known to you or have you seen patient before (when how, where)
Any reason to remember (speech, walk, marks, tattoos etc.)
Time between patient gone missing and your identification to police
Errors and material discrepancies (between initial description and actual description)
